messageBody:
On Tuesday 31 May 2005 15:23, haefeleuser wrote:
> Someone in our team writes his tests like this:
>
> try
> {
> articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
> }
> catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
> {
> assertTrue(true);
> }
>
> He says the does it because otherwise Checkstyle would complain about
> the empty catch block.
>
> I do it in this manner:
>
> try
> {
> articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
> }
> catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
> {
> // Its okay since we expect it.
> }
>
> What do you prefer in the case above: assertTrue(true) or inline
> comment in the catch block?

Neither.

assertTrue(true) looks daft, and the comment won't stop style critics.

I have an empty method in my TestBase class(es), called `pass`, which
I call. It expresses intent and shuts up the local critic.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
"The compiler is free to insert padding because it makes the struct
look bigger and scares away predators." [Keith Thompson, comp.lang.c]
